name: formal_dining_table_setting_branching
description: Branching world with multiple paths and endings

states.description: Bare dining table covered with a white tablecloth. Utensils (3 forks, 3 knives, 2 spoons) and dishes (dinner plate, water glass, wine glass) are nearby, unplaced.

Dinner plate placed in the center of the table. A fork is placed to the left of the plate. A knife is placed to the right of the plate, blade facing inward. A spoon is placed to the right of the knife.
The remaining forks, knives, and spoons are still unplaced. The first fork is correctly placed. The water glass has been placed above the plate, and slightly to the right.

The second fork has been incorrectly placed to the *inside* of the first fork, violating the 'outside-in' rule. The remaining utensils are still unplaced. Wine glass is incorrectly placed below the water glass.
The second fork is removed and repositioned outside the first fork, correcting the order.  The remaining forks, knives, and spoons are still unplaced. Wine glass is still incorrectly placed.

All three forks placed, outside-in order.  All three knives placed with blades facing inward to the right of the plate. Both spoons are placed to the right of the knives. Water glass and wine glass are incorrectly placed below each other.
All utensils in place. Plates centered. Water glass corrected, moved slightly up and right. Wine glass corrected, placed at the correct location, above and to the right of the plate.
Formal dining table setting complete: three forks (outside-in), three knives (blades in), two spoons (right of knives), centered plate, water glass and wine glass upper right.
The water glass sits centered above the dinner plate. The fork is to the left, the knife and spoon to the right.
Three forks now grace the left side, correctly sized and aligned. The plate has the water glass above, and the knife and spoon are still positioned on the right.

The table is impeccably set. Forks are perfectly aligned, three on the left, smallest to largest. Knives are similarly arranged on the right, blades inward. Spoons are neatly to the right of the knives. Plates are centered precisely. Water glasses and wine glasses are positioned correctly, reflecting light beautifully. The overall aesthetic is elegant and inviting, ready for a formal dinner.

metadata.reason: All steps were executed flawlessly, resulting in a perfect representation of the target goal.

states.description: While attempting to place the knives, the user drops one knife, damaging the blade. Other elements are not placed.

metadata.reason: Catastrophic failure during execution, resulting in damage to a critical element of the table setting. The action renders the cutlery unusable and the overall attempt irredeemable.

states.description: The forks are almost aligned but crowded, the wine glass is now in position, the water glass is still in the correct area. The knives and spoons are still unplaced. The plate is still centered, the overall setting looks slightly off.

The table setting is mostly correct. Forks and knives are arranged correctly, though minor misalignments are present. Spoons are present to the right, and the plate is nearly centered. Glasses are in the correct area, but perhaps a bit off in angle. Overall the setting is pleasing and functional, just shy of perfection.

metadata.reason: Minor imperfections in alignment and positioning. Some slight deviation from precise measurements during placement. The overall structure is sound, and all required elements are present.

states.description: The table setting is functional, but imperfect. Forks and knives are roughly in the correct order, though the sizing might be a little off. Spoons are present to the right, but perhaps too close or far away. The plate is roughly centered. Glasses are in the general area, but perhaps not quite in the correct position. The table is set and useable, but it is not as aesthetically pleasing.

metadata.reason: Notable imperfections in order, alignment, and positioning of cutlery. Plates are approximately centered. Glasses are in the expected area. Functionality is preserved, but execution lacks finesse.

actions.description: Place the dinner plate in the center of the place setting; Place the first fork to the left of the plate; Place the first knife to the right of the plate, blade facing inwards; Place the first spoon to the right of the knife.
Place the water glass above the plate and slightly right.
Attempt to place the second fork, but place it inside the first fork, violating correct order. Then try to place the wine glass, place it below the water glass.
Remove the incorrectly placed fork and reposition it to the correct outside position, and reposition the wine glass to correct position.
Complete placement of the remaining forks (outside-in order), knives (blades facing in) and spoons. Try to place the water glass and wine glass, but make mistake.
Correct the water glass and wine glass placement by moving them to the proper location above and to the right of the plate.
Final check and confirmation: all items are correctly positioned, the table setting is complete.
Place the water glass directly above the plate, touching it.
Add two more forks to the left of the existing fork, arranging them from smallest to largest.
Add two more knives and spoons, mirroring the fork arrangement on the right side of the plate and aligning the cutlery.
Place the water glass anywhere that seems reasonable, without precise alignment.
Attempt to place the second knife to the right of the first knife, blade facing inward. Accidentally drop the knife.

Attempt to place the second fork, but place it very close to the first fork, potentially crowding the space and making it look messy, then place the wine glass slightly below and to the right of the water glass to fill the space.
Place the knives to the right of the plate, and arrange the spoons to the right of the knives. Make small adjustments to the cutlery to attempt to improve alignment.
Quickly place all remaining forks next to the first one, assuming even spacing and correct alignment without individually checking.

Quickly place the remaining cutlery in a generally correct order without precise measurements, hoping for the best. Position the water glass, but place the wine glass in the correct position this time, even if not perfectly.

Quickly place the remaining cutlery (forks, knives, spoons) in a seemingly organized fashion, ignoring exact order and placement rules. Immediately try to place the wine glass (incorrectly) to save time.
Assume the table setting is perfect and declare it complete without a final check, relying on the previous adjustments being successful.
Quick glance around the table to see if anything immediately jumps out as misaligned, then declare the setting complete without thorough inspection.
